If every good is in the soul‚ then whatever stmngthens, uplifts, and enlarges the soul, is a good; virtue, however, does make the soul stronger, lostier, and larger. All the actions of life, taken as a whole, are con- trolled by the consideration of what is honourable or base3 it is with reference to these two things that our reason is governed in doing or not doing a particular thing. Nothing will deter him from that which is honourable, and nothing will tempt him into baseness.
